zk_lesson1_title: Lesson 1: What is ZK â€” in simple words
zk_lesson1_paragraph1: Imagine you can <highlight>prove a fact</highlight> without revealing the actual information. For example â€” you want to prove you're over 18 without showing your ID. Thatâ€™s the essence of <highlight>Zero-Knowledge</highlight> â€” proof without disclosure.

zk_lesson3_title: Lesson 3: ZK in real life â€” examples anyone can understand

zk_lesson4_title: Lesson 4: ZK vs Encryption â€” what's the difference?

zk_lesson5_title: Lesson 5: How ZK works â€” a simple explanation of the mechanics
zk_lesson5_paragraph1: Ok, you got it: ZK lets you prove a fact without revealing the details. But how does it work under the hood? Letâ€™s simplify it.
zk_lesson5_paragraph2: ğŸ’¡ At the core of ZK is a <highlight>protocol</highlight> between two sides: the <highlight>prover</highlight> and the <highlight>verifier</highlight>. One proves â€” the other checks. But without revealing the actual info.

zk_lesson5_paragraph4: ğŸ“¦ In modern systems, it's all converted into math â€” so-called <highlight>zk-SNARKs</highlight> or <highlight>zk-STARKs</highlight>. They compress all logic into a short proof thatâ€™s easy to verify.

zk_lesson6_title: Lesson 6: ZK and hashes â€” one-way knowledge magic

zk_lesson7_title: Lesson 7: ZK-SNARKs â€” compressed proofs that are easy to verify
zk_lesson7_paragraph1: ZK-SNARK is one of the most popular proof types in Zero-Knowledge. zk_lesson8_title: Lesson 8: ZK-STARKs â€” transparent alternative without 'magic'
zk_lesson8_paragraph1: ZK-STARK is a modern alternative to SNARK that doesnâ€™t require a trusted setup. The name means <highlight>Scalable Transparent Argument of Knowledge</highlight>. Its main benefits: <highlight>scalability</highlight> and <highlight>transparency</highlight>.

zk_lesson9_title: Lesson 9: ZK-based Rollups â€” zkRollup vs Optimistic Rollup

zk_lesson10_title: Lesson 10: zkEVM and zkVM â€” why they matter and whatâ€™s the difference
zk_lesson10_paragraph1: If youâ€™ve heard terms like <highlight>zkEVM</highlight>, <highlight>zkVM</highlight>, <highlight>Cairo</highlight>, <highlight>LLVM</highlight> â€” donâ€™t worry. These are just different ways to use Zero-Knowledge inside smart contracts and apps.
